instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
Hello,
I have a Macbook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on. No response to the AMP Meter as well.

But very dirty. Cleaned it.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD_SNS</SIGNAL> shorted.

Where do i start?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
What is the exact ohm value of that short?
Compare with the readings on all big coils.
Don't forget L9080/580...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
Its 0 ohms - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
Getting 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.
<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> — 1.00 Ω

<RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> — 1.00 Ω

<RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR> — 1.00 Ω

<RESISTOR>R7062</RESISTOR> — 1.00 Ω

All above are 1.2Ohms.

Should i replace the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> from a donor board ?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
Don't touch <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> yet.
Did you do what I said about the coils from secondary power supplies???

Remove F7000/1 and check which side the short remains.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
L9080 and L9580 - Normal Diode Mode Readings are .395

Removed the FUSE. Short is at Pin #2 <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. 
Diode Mode Readings on Pin #1 is .480

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
OK, check all other big coils.

What is <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage, with both fuses removed?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> is 12.26V without the fuses

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
What do you expect, if is connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>???

I said to compare short value with the readings on all big coils to ground.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message: All Big Coils i am getting diode mode readings which seem normal .300-.500

threads.message:
I doubt you get so high values on CPU/GPU coils.
Please, post exact reading on each coil.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:

L7030 .373 on Both Pins.
L7701 .183 on Both Pins
L8102 is .056 on Both Pins
L7660 is .304 on Both Pins
L8410 is .833 on Both Pins

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
You couldn't find all of them?
Where are the mentioned GPU and CPU coils readings???

GPU coils are hidden under black plastic, in the middle of the board.
Use boardview, please.

BTW, no need to check on both pins of a coil....

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
LA730
LA720
LA740
LA710 

Readings of all are 0.02

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
I said to compare with the reading on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> side.
If no close reading value, then is safe to apply voltage injection method.

But you MUST be very sure have checked ALL coils.
And is not the case here. you still miss some of them!
Really, didn't see L3500, LB700, LA860/70, LA950, L7330, LA750, L7211, L7410???

Of course, check only ONE coil when you have more tied together...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
What do you mean by comparing with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>? i didnt get you. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.001.

L3500 0.418
LB700 0.418
LA860/70 0.036
LA950 .056
LA850 0.073
LA750 0.006
LA7231 0.04
L7330 0.014
L7221 0.002
L7211 0.003
L7420  0.005
L7410 0.005

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
Seems that you have luck; no short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other secondary power rail.
I hope you've posted correct readings.

Now you can inject 1V into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and see what gets hot.
Using IR thermal camera helps you a lot.

Set lab PSU at max current limit.
5A PSU may not help, but try if no better available.
If 1V doesn't help, slowly increase the voltage.
With such pure short (0.001), 1-2V should be more than enough to detect the culprit.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message: I have a 5A PSU only. Let me try and revert back. I have those resin smoke devices that help determining a heating component . Will try that if needed.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message: Found <CAPACITOR>C6466</CAPACITOR> getting very hot. Replaced that. PPBUS is no longer short. Put Back the Fuses. Machine is ON. Thanks.

All big coils reading are similar to what posted above.

Should we inject 1V

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
Did you check all coils?
What about L9080/580?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Response to Amp Meter
threads.message:
Yes all Big Coils. L9080/580 are fine as well. We went ahead and injected 1-2V on our 5A PSU.

<CHIP>U6500</CHIP> was getting hot. Replaced it from a donor board. Short Gone. Machine switched on.
